questions.text: While performing a subtotal thyroidectomy, accidental ligation of which artery can potentially lead to hypoparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Truncal ligation of the inferior thyroid artery can potentially result in hypoparathyroidism. Both superior and inferior parathyroid glands receive their blood from the inferior thyroid artery which arises from the subclavian arteries.Hence during thyroidectomy, only capsular branches closer to the thyroid gland should be ligated.

The inferior parathyroid glands may have a variable blood supply, from either the ascending branch of the inferior thyroid arteries or the thyroid ima artery.

questions.text: Identify the correct pair based on their embryological development.

choices.text: Thymus, Inferior parathyroid gland - Third pharyngeal pouch
Thymus, Superior parathyroid gland - Fourth pharyngeal pouch
Superior and Inferior parathyroid gland - Third pharyngeal arch
Thymus, Superior parathyroid gland - Fourth pharyngeal arch

questions.solution:
The thymus and inferior parathyroid glands originate from the third pharyngeal pouch. They migrate from the upper neck to the mediastinum during embryonic development. Inferior parathyroid glands have more variation in their anatomical position due to a long descent.

The superior parathyroid glands originate from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. They are more constant in their position.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of ectopic parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland is paraesophageal.

The common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands are

  • Paraesophageal - most common
  • Mediastinal 
  • Intrathymic 
  • Intrathyroidal 
  • Carotid sheath 
  • High cervical or undescended 

Ectopic parathyroid is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism. In such cases, treatment involves surgical removal of the gland.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients?
questions.solution:
Cancer is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, whereas hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of hypercalcemia detected incidentally in outpatients. The causes of hypercalcemia in cancer : 

  • Cancers affecting bone like multiple myeloma, leukemia, bony metastasis - cause the bone to break down which releases excess calcium into the blood
  • Pseudohyperparathyroidism - tumours producing parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) cause the bone to release calcium into the blood. The most common carcinoma associated is squamous cell carcinoma of lung.
  • Cancers affecting kidneys - failure to remove excess calcium from the blood
  • Dehydration caused by nausea and vomiting - difficult for the kidneys to remove calcium from the blood properly
  • Lack of physical activity - causes bone breakdown, releasing calcium into the blood

questions.text: What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
A single adenoma is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. They are most often located in the inferior parathyroid glands.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is due to excess or non-suppressed PTH secretion from the following:

  • Single parathyroid adenoma 
  • Multiple adenomas 
  • Hyperplasia 
  • Carcinoma 

Sporadic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is more common than familial (MEN syndrome/ familial HPT/ Familial HPT with jaw tumor syndrome). Women are affected more commonly than men.

questions.text: Lab investigations in a patient with fatigue and colicky abdominal pains show elevated PTH and calcium, and low serum phosphate. Which of the following ophthalmic findings is pathognomonic of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Band keratopathy is pathognomonic of this condition. It is due to the deposition of calcium phosphate crystals in the cornea. 

In patients with elevated PTH, calcium and phosphate levels are measured. Elevated calcium and decreased phosphate levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Normal calcium and elevated phosphate levels are suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

The image given below shows band keratopathy.

Option A: Kayser Fleischer rings are brownish-yellow rings in the corneoscleral junction due to the deposition of copper in the cornea. 

Option C: Ocular chrysiasis is the deposition of gold in the cornea, after repeated parenteral administration of gold salts. 

Option D: Hudson Stahli line is a superficial brown line at the junction of the upper 2/3 and lower 1/3 of the cornea in an otherwise normal cornea. It is attributed to the deposition of iron.

questions.text: During a clinical trial, it was found that some individuals who showed radioactive uptake on Sestamibi scan, showed no other evidence of hyperparathyroidism. They were instead found to be suffering from a Hurthle cell nodule of the thyroid gland. Which of the following radioactive tracer tests could be used to rule out the false positives?
questions.solution:
A thyroid-specific tracer like 99Tc-Pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images could be used to rule out the false positives caused by the solid thyroid nodules such as Hurthle cell nodule.

The Sestamibi scanning is a nuclear-based imaging test used to localize the parathyroid glands. Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation that accumulates in mitochondria. Due to this, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending upon the number of mitochondria in each tissue. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content and they retain tracers and have a slower washout compared to the normal glands.

In patients with nodular goiter or functional tumors of the thyroid gland, increased uptake of sestamibi by the thyroid gland makes parathyroid visualization difficult. There are two primary techniques to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue:

  • Dual-isotope subtraction imaging (with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or 99mTc pertechnetate) -  99mTc pertechnetate is taken up only by the thyroid. The 99mTc pertechnetate scintigram is then digitally subtracted from the sestamibi scan to allow parathyroid localization.
  • Single-isotope dual-phase imaging (with sesta­mibi alone with early and delayed imaging) - since the rate of washout from the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland is slower when compared to the thyroid gland.

The image given below shows the dual-isotope subtraction imaging.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease of bone
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

 The image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.  
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.  
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.

The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan.

questions.text: In a patient with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, when will you perform parathyroidectomy?

choices.text: If bone mineral density of  > 2.5 SD above peak bone mass
In the presence of hypercalciuria but absence of nephrolithiasis
If creatinine clearance is reduced by 30%

questions.solution:
Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30% is an indication for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism.

Related Pearl: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal
  • Renal: 
    • Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%
    • 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day
    • Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis
  • Skeletal: 
    • Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)
    • Presence of vertebral fracture
  • Age <50 years

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady with a history of multiple pathological fractures and renal stones was diagnosed with parathyroid hyperplasia involving all four glands. Which of the following treatment modalities will you use to treat her?

choices.text: Complete removal of all four glands alone
Complete removal of three glands with a partial resection of the least affected gland
Partial resection of the affected glands with autotransplantation of the least affected gland

questions.solution:
Hyperplasia involving all four parathyroid glands is treated by complete removal of three glands with partial resection of the least affected gland (Subtotal parathyroidectomy). Total cervical parathyroidectomy with heterotropic transplantation can also be done in this patient.

Modes of treatment for parathyroid hyperplasia:

  1. Subtotal parathyroidectomy - The affected glands are completely removed and the least affected gland is partially resected. The remnants left behind should ideally be 30 mg. A lower gland is preferred because its location reduces the risk of injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. 
  2. Total parathyroidectomy with heterotopic transplantation - All 4 parathyroid glands are removed and parathyroid tissue is immediately transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

Complications of parathyroidectomy include:

  • Persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Hungry bone syndrome
  • Injury to recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Autotransplantation was done after total parathyroidectomy in a patient with hyperplasia of all 4 parathyroid glands. Which of the following best describes this procedure?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid is transplanted heterotopically i.e. organ is implanted in another anatomic location.

In total parathyroidectomy, all 4 parathyroid glands are removed and parathyroid tissue is immediately transplanted to the brachioradialis muscle in the non-dominant forearm.

questions.text: Parathyroid gland post surgery  is commonly transferred to:
questions.solution:
The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. This will facilitate easy removal if there is disease recurrence after surgery.

Parathyroidectomy is indicated in:

  1. Symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT):  
  2. Asymptomatic primary HPT with:
    • raise in serum calcium >1mg/dl of the normal range
    • >400 mg urinary calcium in 24-hour urine test
    • < -2.5 Z-score of bone mineral density
    • Age <50yr and failed medical treatment 
  3. Severe cases of secondary HPT

Parathyroidectomy is performed in neck hyperextension (semi-Fowler position). The thyroid gland is mobilized, and the parathyroid gland with adenoma is identified and resected. The parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm.

Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted. This is a type of heterotopic transplant.

Miami criteria (confirm the absence of another hyperactive parathyroid): A drop of parathyroid hormone intraoperatively, to more than half the maximum value at 10 minutes postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

Complications of parathyroidectomy include:

  1. Persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism
  2. Hypoparathyroidism (presenting as hypocalcemia)
  3. Hungry bone syndrome
  4. Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below)

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about secondary hyperparathyroidism?

choices.text: Lithium intake may cause secondary hyperparathyroidism
Calciphylaxis is seen in early stages

questions.solution:
Calciphylaxis (calcific uremic arteriolopathy) is a disseminated calcification seen late in the course of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

In calciphylaxis, the underlying calcification in the vascular and arteriolar walls → ischemic necrosis → ulceration and gangrene → sepsis → death.

It presents as an expanding cutaneous lesion which is predominantly seen in the extremities and lower abdomen. Prognosis is poor and an urgent parathyroidectomy is shown to increase median survival.

Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Chronic renal failure (most common)
  • Vitamin D3 deficiency
  • GI malabsorption
  • Lithium intake

To minimize the risk of missing parathyroid glands, transcervical thymectomy should be considered as a routine part of total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation and subtotal parathyroidectomy. In addition, careful cervical exploration for secondary hyperparathyroidism should be carried out.

The image below shows calciphylaxis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents to the OPD with complaints of recent onset pain in her feet. Blood investigation showed elevated PTH levels and normal serum calcium values. All of the following mechanisms contribute to elevated PTH in this patient except _____

choices.text: Stimulation of parathyroid cells by hyperphosphatemia
Increased secretion of FGF-23 by osteocytes
Reduced expression of Vitamin D receptors and CaSR (calcium-sensing receptor) in bones
Interference with parathyroid kinase C signal transduction pathway and Wnt pathway

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described here showing elevated PTH and normal calcium levels is that of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure. Interference with parathyroid kinase C signal transduction pathway and Wnt pathway is the proposed mechanism of secondary hyperparathyroidism in the setting of lithium consumption and not renal hyperparathyroidism.

Causes for increased PTH in secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure:

  • Abnormal renal tubular reabsorption → hyperphosphatemia → stimulation of parathyroid cells → elevated PTH
  • Increased FGF-23 secretion from osteocytes →  decreased 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D → decreased intestinal absorption of calcium → elevated PTH
  • Normally, ECF calcium controls PTH secretion by interacting with CaSR. Stimulation of CaSR by high calcium suppresses PTH secretion. In chronic renal disease, there is reduced expression of Vitamin D and CaSR by bones → increased skeletal resistance to PTH → elevated PTH.

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient is undergoing focussed parathyroidectomy for parathyroid adenoma. According to the Miami criteria, for the resection to be considered adequate, the intraoperative drop in parathyroid hormone should be ______.

choices.text: More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in half an 30 min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 30 min

questions.solution:
Drop of parathyroid hormone to more than half the maximum value at 10 min postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma by the Miami criteria.

Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay for Miami criteria.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to >50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue, vomiting, abdominal cramps and bone pain. She had undergone total parathyroidectomy and heterotopic autotransplantation for the same complaints 8 months ago. Sestamibi scan was done and found to be normal. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Post her for bilateral neck exploration
Label her as persistent hyperparathyroidism and start her on medical management

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent hyperparathyroidism which could be due to recurrence in the neck or graft (graft hyperplasia). The next step would be to perform Casnova test to differentiate between them, as Sestamibi scan has ruled out ectopic parathyroid.

Casanova test involves selective venous sampling for PTH levels from neck veins and brachial veins. If PTH from the brachial venous sample is >20 times that of neck vein sample, graft hyperplasia is confirmed.

Persistent parathyroidism is defined as hypercalcemia that fails to resolve after parathyroidectomy i.e. within 6 weeks of surgery. Recurrent parathyroidism is hyperparathyroidism that occurs after an intervening period of at least 6 months of biochemically documented normocalcemia. Causes of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism include:

  • Ectopic parathyroid
  • Unrecognized hyperplasia - graft site hyperplasia
  • Missed adenoma in normal position
  • Incomplete resection
  • Familial hyperparathyroidism
  • MEN-1 syndrome

The image below summarises the management protocol for a case of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism.

*FHH stands for Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

questions.text: All of the following are indications for surgical intervention of tertiary hyperparathyroidism except ____

choices.text: Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland

questions.solution:
Reduced serum phosphate is not an indication for surgical intervention in tertiary hyperparathyroidism. 

Renal transplantation in patients with chronic kidney diseases may be associated with autonomous functioning of the parathyroid gland. This is called tertiary hyperparathyroidism where there is hypercalcemic hyperparathyroidism.

The indications for surgical intervention in tertiary hyperparathyroidism are as follows :

  • Subacute severe hypercalcaemia (>3 mmol/L)
  • Impaired graft function
  • Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland(s)
  • Progressive symptoms for >2 years following transplantation
    • Worsening bone disease - pain, fractures, bone loss
    • Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis
    • Soft tissue or vascular calcifications

questions.text: A 75-year-old lady with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis presents with hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated PTH. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient’s long-standing renal failure and elevated calcium, phosphate, and PTH are suggestive of tertiary hyperparathyroidism. This form of hyperparathyroidism can be life-threatening, and all patients with it should be referred for surgical intervention. 

The surgical procedure of choice for tertiary hyperparathyroidism is subtotal parathyroidectomy. In subtotal parathyroidectomy, the affected glands are completely removed and the least affected gland is partially resected.  

Option A: Total parathyroidectomy without an autograft is not a treatment option due to the postoperative and persistent difficulties in managing the associated hypocalcemia.

Option C: Minimally invasive approaches commonly refer to the removal of a localized abnormal parathyroid gland through an incision less than 3cm in length. It is based on the principle that over 80% of individuals with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma. It is contraindicated in multi-glandular disease, lithium-induced hyperparathyroidism, and hyperparathyroidism associated with familial syndromes.

Option D: Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic used in the treatment of secondary hyperparathyroidism. The use of calcimimetics in tertiary hyperparathyroidism remains controversial and has not been approved for this indication.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with a history of treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma in childhood presents with severe abdominal cramps and right flank pain. He has a firm 2x2cm mass in the front of his neck. He has a Calcium of 15.2 mg/dl, normal TSH, markedly elevated PTH, and PGP9.5+ on immunohistochemistry. What is the leading cause of mortality in his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. With early-onset, neck mass, and positive IHC for PGP9.5+, it is concerning for parathyroid cancer. Hypercalcemia is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with parathyroid cancer. 

Parathyroid cancer is a rare malignancy and makes up 1% of cases of primary hyperparathyroidism. History of prior neck radiation is considered to be a risk factor. Patients usually present a decade earlier than primary hyperparathyroidism (5th - 6th decade), with an equal preponderance in males and females. Patients may present with a neck mass and severely elevated calcium and PTH levels.

Treatment is focused on controlling hypercalcemia and surgery is the mainstay.

Option B: Cardiovascular disease is a major contributing cause of mortality in patients with hyperthyroidism and chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: In patients with parathyroid carcinoma, which of the following treatment modalities would you not consider?

choices.text: En-bloc excision of the tumor and ipsilateral thyroid lobe with MRND

questions.solution:
Etelcalcetide has no role in the treatment of parathyroid carcinoma. It is ineffective.

Etelcalcetide is a calcium-sensing receptor agonist used to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism in adult patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis.

Treatment modalities for parathyroid carcinoma:

  • Surgical - Bilateral neck exploration + En-bloc excision of the tumor and ipsilateral thyroid lobe with/without MRND (Modified radical neck dissection) in presence of lymph node metastasis.
  • Pharmacological:
    • Cinacalcet hydrochloride, a calcimimetic, can reduce PTH levels by directly binding to the CaSR (calcium-sensing receptor) cells on the parathyroid gland; used to control hypercalcemia in refractory parathyroid carcinoma. 
    • Azidothymidine (telomerase inhibitor)
    • Octreotide 
    • Anti-parathyroid hormone immunotherapy
  • Radiation therapy - for unresectable disease or for palliation of bone metastases

Risk factors for parathyroid carcinoma incude:

  • Radiation exposure
  • Hyperparathyroidism jaw bone syndrome 
    • HPRT gene or parafibromin inactivation

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with severe hypercalcemia. His father had similar complaints and was found to have hyperparathyroid-jaw tumour syndrome. Which of the following is pathognomonic of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ossifying jaw fibromas are a pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroid-jaw tumour syndrome. It arises due to inactivating mutations in the HRPT2 gene on chromosome 1 q21-32, encoding parafibromin.

It is a rare cause of primary hyperparathyroidism with an early onset (32 years) which presents with severe hypercalcemia. It is associated with an increased risk of parathyroid carcinoma and other conditions like polycystic kidney disease. Surgical intervention may be considered to remove all enlarged glands.

Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a feature of hyperparathyroidism but is not considered pathognomonic of any condition.
